4. Discussion 
Plants are an important source for drug discovery, par­
ticularly for antiparasitic drugs, due to the coexistence of 
parasites and humans, and the prevalence of herbal reme­
dies. For centuries, medicinal plants have been used to 
combat parasitism and are still used for this purpose in 
many parts of the world (Anthony et al.. 2005). The AH 
activity of plant extracts has been attributed to the sec­
ondary metabolites that may be extracted from the raw 
plant material (Domínguez. 1979). 
In viera tests using L3 larvae of H. cantartus are consid­
ered to be one of the best means of screening for the AH 
activity of new plant compounds (Asase et al.. 2005). In 
the present study, using the LMI assay against H. cancarrus, 
the ethanolic (2 mg/mL) and dichloromethane (3 mgfmL) 
extracts of P. icasandra both showed significant inhibition 
of migration with 55.4% and 67.1% inhibition, respectively . 
However, the dichloromethane extraer of P. icasandra was 
the only one that showed a dose-dependent response 
(Fig. 1 ). This pasitive regression demonstrates that increas­
ing conc.entrations of the plant extract produced greater 
inhibition of larval migration ; however, a positive regres­
sion was not found in the ethanolic extraer. This suggests 
further in viera experiments to test the isolation and identi­
fication of active compounds of both plant extracts would 
be useful. 
In previous studies, similar or higher concentrations of 
plant extracts ha ve been used to control H. cantarrus (Costa 
et al., 2008; Alonso-Díaz et al., 2008; Manolaraki et al., 
201 0). Alonso-Díaz et al. (2008) using Lysilama latisiliquu m, 
Acacia pennatula and Leucaena lucacephala, showed that 
1.2 mgf mL of plant extr act inhibited 33.0%, 43.0% a nd 44.0% 
of larval migration of H. cantarrus, respectively . Manolaraki 
et al. (2010) using Pistacia ler~t íscus, Quercus coccifera, Cero­
car~ia si/iqua, Castanea sativa, Pyrus spi11osa and Onabryc/lis 
viciifo/ia, showed that 1.2 mgfmL of plant extraer inhib­
ited 79.1%, 63.8%, 61.5%, 54.6%. 47.4% and 38.9% of larval migration of H. cantortus, respectively . Costa et al. (2008 ), 
using Azadiraclrta indica, showed that 15.7 mgfmL of plant 
extraer was needed to inhibit 50% of the larval develop­
m~nt ofH. car~torru s.ln the present study, 0.90 mgfmLofthe 
dichloromethane extraer from P. icasandra was required to 
produce 50% larval migration inhibition (Fig. 1 ). 
In the egg hatch assay, gr~ater than 95% of egg hatch 
inhibition was found in the ~thanolic and dichloromethan~ 
extracts from P. icasandra at 1.8 and 0.90 mgfmL, respec­
tively. The ethanolic and dichloromethane extracts at these 
concentrations have shown a similar leve! of effectiveness 
when compared to th~ synthetic AH drug, as 0.5 Jl,g/mL of 
thiabendazole inhibited 95.0-98.0% of egg hatching. Thi­
abendazole is a pure substance , while the ethanolic and 
dichloromethane extracts contained sever al chemical com­
pounds, with the active ingredient with ovicidal action 
present in small amounts. An important advantage of the 
P. icasar~dra extracts over thiabendazole is that it is a natu­
ral product that can be locally grown and obtained at low 
cost. In general, the extraer of a plant has only small con­
centrations of the active compounds anda great number 
of promising properties (Rates, 2001 ). The egg hatching 
could have been inhibit~d by the saponins in the ethanolic 
extraer. as these molecules are known to stop H. cor~tar­
cus from egg hatching (Camurca-Vasconce los et al., 2007; 
Eguale et al., 2007). 
The AH activity of P. icosa11dra could be attributable to 
the coumarins, flavonoids , steroids, terpenoids or combina­
tions ofthese present in the dichloromethane and ethanolic 
extracts; orto the saponins present in the ethanolic ~xtract. 
Coumarins are known to have a variety of biologi­
cal activities . Wang et al. (2008) provided evidence that 
coumarins possess nematodicida l activities against two 
plant parasitic nematodes (8ursaplrelerrc/ws xylopfri/us and 
Par~agrellus redivivus). 
Saponins ha ve also been reported to ha ve nematodicidal 
activity. D'Addabbo et al. (201 O) found that saponins were 
nematotoxic to thr~e phytoparasit ic species (Xíplrimerra 
i11dex, Meloidagyr~e irrcagnira and C/abadera rastoclriertsis) 
and that their activity was dependent on the concentration 
and nematode incubation time. In another study, Gnoula 
et al. (2007) isolated a steroidal saponin (Balanitin-7) and 
demonstrated a high leve! of AH activity against the free liv­
ing nematade Caenarlrabditís elegans. The biological effects 
of saponins ar~ normally ascribed to their specific interac­
tion with the cell membranes , causing changes in cell wall

permeabiliry (Sparg et al., 2004; Tava and Avato. 2006). 
Saponins are also able to interact with collagen proteins 
from the cuticles of nematodes . and this interaction may be 
responsible for the nematotoxic effects (Heng et al.. 2004; 
Argentieri et al., 2008 ). 
Lee et al. (2008) screened various naturally occurring 
flavonoids for AH activiry and showed that these com­
pounds caused both embryonic and larval lethaliry in C 
elegans. The biochemical and pharmacological activities of 
flavonoids have been attributed to their anti-oxidative and 
free-radicalscavenging properties (Middleton et al.. 2000); 
however. the molecular basis of the high embryonic and 
larval lethaliry of flavonoids on C. elegans still needs to be 
elucidated (Lee et al .• 2008). 
Although saponins present in P. icosandra have showed 
sorne haemolytic properties on bovine erythrocytes 
(Treyvaud et al.. 2000). and sorne coumarin s in other plants 
(i.e. Metilotus oflicinatis) have showed anticoagulant prop­
erties which can cause the deaths of livestock by interna! 
bleeding (Dewick. 2002) plants of the genus P/Jyco/acca 
(P. dodecandra) have been used for medicinal purposes in 
humans and animals (Esseret al.. 2003). Plants ofthe genus 
P/Jytolacca are rich in total protein (>25%) and in Ethiopia 
is reported that goats and cattle fed on P. dodecandra 
although animal intake will depend on fodder availability 
(Esser et al.. 2003). The possible toxic effect of P. icosan­
dra (haemolyticand anticoagulant properties)and required 
animal intakes to promote adequate AH effects still need to 
be investigated. 
In conclusion. the ethanolic and dichloromethane 
extracts from P. icosandra showed a clear in vitro AH activ­
iry against H. contortus L3 larvae and eggs. The hexanic 
extraer from P. ícosandro failed to show any in vítro AH 
activiry. The AH activiry of P. ícosandra can be attributable 
to the coumarins. flavonoids. steroids. terpenoids andfor 
saponins orto the combined interaction of all of the com­
ponents. In view of this finding. it is proposed that further 
in vitro and in vivo studies of different plant parts and 
extracts. including the isolation and identification of the 
active compounds, should be carried out to further eval­
uare their potential as AH drugs. The potential for toxic 
effects of P. icosandra (haemolytic properties) on animals 
rema in to be investigated .

Abstract 
The in vivo anthelmintic (AH) activity of the ethanolic extract from leaves of Phyto/acca 
icosandra was evaluated in goats artificially infected with Haemonchus contortus. Parasite 
na"ive goats were artificially infected with 3000 H. contortus infective larvae per animal. 
Once the infection was patent (day 28 post-infection) all the animals were sampled to 
determine the faecal egg counts (FEC) for five consecutive days. Two groups of animals 
were formed balanced for their FEC and body-weight (BW) (n = 6 /group): the non-treated 
control group and the treated group in which goats were individually administered with the 
ethanolic extract of P. icosandra . The extract was administered orally using gelatin 
capsules (250 mg/kg BW) which were dosed on two consecutive days using a pill­
dispenser. Faecal samples were collected from each animal from the day of dosage (Day 
O) on a daily basis to determine the number of eggs per gram of feces (EPG) for 15 days 
post-treatment (PT). The FEC of the two groups were compared using the repeated 
meas u res analyses of variance using the log transformed data Ln (FEC+1). The presence 
of saponins , coumarins , flavonoids, steroids and terpenoids were detected by standard 
methodologies in the extract. The P. icosandra ethanolic extract was further analyzed by 
gas chromatog raphy (GC) coupled to a mass spectrometry (GC 1 MS). A significant 
reduction in FEC was observed in the treated group compared to the control from day 7 
until day 15 PT (P <0.05). The highest percentage reduction (72 %) was found on day 11 
PT. No adverse reactions were observed in all treated animals for the entire trial. The 
GC/MS analysis of the organic extracts revealed the presence of three fatty acids as 
compounds with highest abundance . The three compounds that were identified by their 
mass fragmentation patterns were: 2-Pentadecanone, 6, 1 O, 14-trimethyl (RT 10.3 
minutes), Pentadecanoic acid, 14-methyl- , methyl ester (RT 10.8 minutes) and 
Hexadecanoic acid, ethyl ester (RT 11.2 minutes). lt is concluded that the P. icosandra 
ethanolic extract obtained from leaves showed in vivo anthelmintic activity against H. 
contortus when administered orally to goats at a dose of 250 mg/kg BW on two 
consecutive days. The dose used did not cause any negative effects on the health of 
goats.

1. lntroduction 
The nematode parasite, Haemonchus contortus , is an important nematode pathogen of 
small ruminants in the production systems based on grazing or browsing (Waller et al., 
2006). The mortality rates due to gastrointestinal nematode (GIN) infections , in which H. 
contortus can make an important contribution, may exceed 40 %, while weight losses of 
50 % may occur under tropical conditions (Githigia et al., 2001; Torre,s-Acosta et al., 
2004). Conventional anthelmintic (AH) drugs have been used to minimize the effect of 
those parasites in ruminants . However , the sustainability of this control method has been 
compromi sed due to the emergence of H. contortus strains resistant to different AH 
families (Kaplan, 2004; Canui-Ku et al., 2011 ). The anthelmintic resistan ce problem and 
the growing demand for animal products free from chemical residues, has led to the 
development of alternative methods for the control helminths in small ruminant production 
systems (Jackson and Miller, 2006; Torres-Acos ta and Hoste, 2008). The use of 
traditional medicinal plants, or ethnoveterinary alternatives (based on medicina l plants), is 
considered a viable options for the control of GIN amongst small-scale goat farmers who 
cannot pay for allopathic drugs (Tarik et al., 2009). Studies from various parts of the world 
have shown that certain plant species effectively reduce the parasite burden and are 
promising alternatives to conventional AH (Githiori et al., 2006). The tropical pokeweed , 
Phytolacc a icosandra , belongs to the Phytolaccaceae family. lt is a flowering plant that is 
native to tropics of North, Central and South America (from Mexico to Peru) and it can be 
found in the Caribbean islands. The berries from P. icosandra have traditionally been 
used as soap for washing cotton clothes and also have molluscicidal and spermicidal 
activity (Treyvaud et al., 2000). The leaves and roots are used for various human and 
animal ailments such as scabies, ringworm, dandruff, itching, headache , rheumatism , skin 
irritations, stomach pain and intestinal roundworms of children (Ascaris spp.) (Fonnegra 
and Jimenez, 2007). A previous study reported the in vitro AH efficacy against H. 
contortus eggs (egg-hatch assay) and larvae (larval migration inhibition test) when using 
the ethanolic or the dichloromethane extracts from the leaves of P. icosandra (Hernández­
Villegas et al., 2011 ). The in vivo efficacy of this plant extract has not been evaluated . The 
aim of the present study was to evaluate the in vivo AH efficacy of the ethanolic extract 
obtained from P. icosandra leaves against H. contortus in goats.

2. Materials and methods 
2.1 Plant materials 
The P. icosandra leaves were collected in Yaxcabá, Yucatán, Mexico (20°33' N and 
88°49' W) in January 2011. The voucher specimen was authenticated and deposited in 
the herbarium of the Centro de Investigación Científica de Yucatán (CICY) under the 
following code number: P. icosandra MMéndez 1497. 
2.2 Production of the plant extract 
The extract was obtained from a sample of 1000 g of dry P. icosandra leaves. The leaves 
were dried at 40 oc for 72 h and ground in a grinder with a 5mm diameter mesh. The 
ground material was immersed in 100 % ethanol for 72 h (using 1.0 ml of ethanol per 
0.83 g of ground material). The ethanol extract was filtered and evaporated at 45°C in a 
vacuum rotary evaporator (Buchi®) to give the crude ethanolic extract (liquid form). This 
process of maceration was repeated three times. The crude plant extract was transferred 
to glass vials and was kept at 4 oc until its use. 
2.3 Phytochemic al study 
Phytochemical tests to detect the presence of flavonoids , steroids and terpenoids were 
performed on the ethanolic extract following the methodology previously described by 
Domínguez (1979). The tests were based on the visual observation of colour change or 
the formation of precipitates after the addition of specific reagents. To detect the presence 
of different metabolites in the ethanolic extracts of P. icosandra leaves, the Shinoda 
(flavonoids) , Salkowsky (steroids and terpenoids) and foam-haemolys is (saponins) tests 
were used. In addition, the determination of the colour under UV light was used to detect 
the presence of coumarins (Lock, 1994). Gas chromatography coupled to a mass 
spectrometer detector (GC-MS) was used to separate and identify the volatile, semi­
volatile and thermally stable molecules (or metabolites , or compounds) of a mixture; this 
technique allows the evaluation of the number of compounds that could be vaporized in 
the ethanolic extract of P. icosandra.The GC-MS equipment was an, Agilent Technolog ies 
6890N Gas Chromatography Apparatus coupled with a mass selective detector 5973, 
using the following chromatographic conditions : split injection of 1 ml of a 1 % 
concentration sample: column HP5 MS of phenyl methyl silicone 30m x 0.25mm, flow rate 
71 • 
Capitulo IV 
1.0 mllmin (helium as carrier gas). A sample was analyzed with the column held initially 
at 80°C for 1 m in, increasing 15°C/min, up to 300°C end of the run time. 
The results related to the number of compounds present on a sample can be presented 
as a graph with an x-axis that shows the retention time (RT) of a compound , and the y­
axis that shows the intensity (abundance) of the signa! (compound). lnformation related to 
the mass fragmentation pattern of each compound (signa!) can be obtained as a graph 
where each peak represents an ion derived from the molecular ion (molecular weight) 
after its fragmentation in proportion of their abundance . The identification of components 
in the extract was performed by a computer-based library search. The fragmentation 
patterns of the mass spectra were compared with those from the NIST05 Libraries. 
2.4 lnfective larvae 
Third-stage larvae of H. contortus were obtained from a donor sheep infected with a pure 
strain (CENID-INIFAP , sheep strain, México). When infection became patent (presence of 
nematode eggs in faeces) the faecal material was collected twice daily from each animal. 
The faeces obtained from the donor sheep were cultured at 28 °C for 7 days. The 
resulting third stage larvae {L3) were harvested using a modified Corticelli-Lai (Rodríguez­
Vivas and Cob-Galera, 2005). The infective larvae were counted and stored in water at 4 
°C. One month old larvae were used to infect the experimental goats. 
2.5 Experimental animals 
The experiment was performed at the Facultad de Medicina Veterinaria y Zootecnia­
Universidad Autónoma de Yucatán (20°52' N, 88°37' W) during February-May 2011. 
Twelve three-month old Criollo female goats were used (average body-weight) (BW) of 
(11.6±1.79 kg). Animals were raised free of gastrointestinal nematode infection as 
described by Torres-Acosta et al. (2004). In brief, kids-were kept together with their dams 
for the first five days of life to allow adequate consumption of colostrum . After that the 
dams were removed but were allowed back into the pens to allow kids to suckle milk for 1 
h each morning and afternoon until weaning at 2 months of age. After each visit, all feces 
were removed from the pen. From 15 days of age onwards, animals received a 
concentrate feed which was similar to that used in the trial. Coprological examinations 
were performed with a modified McMaster technique (Rodríguez-Vivas and Cob-Galera, 
2005) at 15 day intervals to confirm that the animals were maintained worm-free . The 
goats were raised indoors on concrete floor pens to avoid nematode infections . Each 
animal was orally inoculated with 3000 H. contortus infective larvae {L3). The larvae were

suspended in a volume of 5 mL of purified water. On day 28 after infection, the presence 
of adult H. contortus worms was confirmed (presence of nematode eggs in feces). Once 
the infection was patent, faecal samples were obtained on 5 consecutive days to obtain a 
mean value of faecal eggs for each experimental animal prior to their distribution in the 
experimen tal groups. 
2.6 Treatment 
The goats used for the study were divided in two experimental groups (six animals each) 
stratified by faecal egg counts (FEC). The treated group received 250 mg/kg BW of the 
ethanolic extract of P. icosandra which were administered orally in gelatin capsules (size 
00). The same dose was offered on two consecutive days. The control group received 
only the gelatin capsules. The capsules were administered to the animals using a pill­
dispenser in the morning before the feed was offered to the animals. The animals were 
maintained without food for 17 hours before the capsules were offered. Clean drinking 
water was available at all times. The dose level (250 mg/kg BW) was determined based 
on a previous pilot study where naturally infected goats were treated on a single day using 
the extract directly to the mouth (Hernández-Villegas unpublished data). The dose level of 
the pilot study was also based on a dose level previously reported with plant crude 
ethanolic extracts of different plants against natural GIN infections of sheep (Ademola et 
al., 2004,2005 ,2007a,2007b). 
For the duration of the trial the experimental animals received a balanced diet that was 
offered to each goat in their individual concrete floor pen (Concentrate feed 300g 
/animal/day and Panicum maximum hay 1 kg of hay/animal/day). The feed allowed a 
weight gain of 11 O g per day. On the day of extract dosage, and for the duration of the trial 
(15 days post-treatment (PT), the animals were observed for abnormal behavior or any 
sign of illness or discomfort. Normal feed consumption was considered a sign of good 
health. Consistency of feces was also recorded daily in individuals. 
2.7 Faecal egg counts 
Faecal samples were collected directly from the rectum of each animal in the morning, 
starting from day O and every day for 15 days PT. The eggs per gram of feces (EPG) were 
determined with the McMaster technique (saccharose solution with a density of 1.3 g/ml) 
as mentioned above. The number of eggs in 2 g of feces was determined in the McMaster 
counting chamber with 2 x 0.15 mi volume of chambers. The counted volume of 0.3 mi of 
faecal suspension represents 1/50 g feces. Thus, the number of EPG was calculated by

Capitulo IV 
multiplying each egg found in the chamber by 50 (Rodríguez -Vivas and Cob-Galera, 
2005). 
2.8 Data analyses. 
2.8.1 Percentage reduction of faecal egg counts. 
The percentage reduction of the FEC between the treated and the control group was 
calculated every day using the faecal egg count reduction test (FECRT) using the 
arithmetic means (Coles et al., 1992): Percentage reduction = 1 00*(1-(T/C)). Where T is 
the treated group and C is the control group respectively . 
2.8.2 Statistical analyses. 
The difference in the EPG of the two experimental groups over time was analyzed using 
the repeated measures analysis of variance using the PROC Mixed of the SAS software 
package for Windows . The model defined the dependent variable EPG, and independent 
variables treatment , day and treatment*day interaction . The repeated statement defined 
the variance structure for repeated measurements . The subject (kid) defined the variable 
on which repeated measurements were taken. The type of variance-covariance structure 
used was compound symmetry as it showed better fit than other variance structures 
analyzed (unstructured, autoregressive and Toeplitz). Befare the analysis the EPG data 
were log transformad (LN (EPG + 1 )). The normal distribution of the log transformad data 
was confirmad with the PROC Univariate of the SAS software package for Windows . 
3. Results 
The present in vivo trial explorad the in vivo AH effect of the ethanolic extract of P. 
icosandra against H. contortus in artificially infectad goats. The treatment scheme used 
caused no adverse reaction to the experimental kids. The dose of the ethanolic extract 
had an important AH effect on the EPG from day 7 PT onwards. The average faecal egg 
reduction percentage was 66 % and the highest percentage reduction was found on day 
11 PT (72 %) (P <0.05) comparad to the control group. A significant reduction in the mean 
FEC (expressed as an arithmetic mean of EPG) was demonstrated (57.0-72.0 %). The 
dose selected for the present trial (250 mg/kg BW) and the mode of administration (dosed 
orally on two consecutiva days) showed a significant effect on the EPG in goats treated 
with the P. icosandra extract comparad to the control group (Figure 1 ). 
The result of the phytochemical screening of the ethanolic extract of P. icosandra leaves 
revealed the presence of compounds that are known to possess various pharmacologic

The preliminary study helped to define the dose leve! to be used for the study but it also 
showed a further complication when attempting to dose the P. icosandra liquid extract to 
goats: animals were refusing to receive the oral dose of the extract when offered in a 
syringe directly to the mouth. Thus, the second decision was to use gelatin capsules (size

A third decision was to dose the goats on two consecutive' days rather than on a single 
dose. This protocol was also used for the in vivo trials testing plant extracts in sheep by 
Ademola et al. (2004, 2005; 2007a, 2007b). Such procedure would have the advantage of 
increasing the chances of exposing the worms to the extract for longer time (similar to the 
"smart drenching" proposed by Hennessy et al. (2000). This dosage scheme may facilitate 
the arrival of the extract to the abomasum where the H. contortus are located. Future 
studies should try to identify the minimum effective dose of extract (or its metabolites) 
reaching the abomasum. 
A reduction of the EPG of H. contortus was found from day 7 PT and remained for the 
duration of the tria!. Compared to the present study with P. icosandra extract, other 
studies have also shown reductions in FEC when using different plant extracts. Ademola 
et al. (2004) tested the ethanolic crude extract of Khaya senegalensis against natural GIN 
infections in sheep and calculated that H. contortus egg production was reduced by 71.5 
% at day 12 PT when using a dose of 500 mg/kg on two days, which is double the dose 
used with the P. icosandra extract in the present tria!. Also, Ademola et al. (2007a) found 
reduction s in EPG when evaluating the ethanolic extract of Spigelia anthelmia in naturally 
infected sheep (73 % at a dose of 250 mg/kg). Also, the work by Shaibani et al. (2009) 
found similar EPG reduction when testing the ethanoJic extract of Fumaria parviflora in 
sheep infected naturally (77 % at day 14 PT with a dose of 200 mg/kg). Finally, Gradé et 
al. (2008) also found similar egg count reductions when using Albizia anthelmintica 
administered directly inside gel capsules in sheep infected naturally (66.5 % ata dose of 
358 mg/kg). The latter was the only previous work using capsules to dose the extract. 
Other studies with plant extracts showed higher reductions in EPG when using higher 
extract doses (1 or 3 g/kg) in naturally infected sheep. Tarik et al., (2009) tested an 
ethanolic extract of Artemisia absinthium, Bachaya et al. (2009) used a methanolic extract 
of Acacia ni/otica and lqbal et al. (2006) with a methanolic extract of Nicotiana tabacum. 
However, a higher dose not always produces a stronger effect on EPG. Hounzangbe-

lt is not possible to compare our results with other workers using other sources of plant 
extracts where the dose was not clearly stated in terms of the quantity per kg of BW 
(Paolini et al., 2003; Gathuma et al., 2004). 
lt is not possible to determine if the AH activity of the P. icosandra extract against H. 
contortus could be attributed to nematodicidal activity orto the temporary suppression of 
female egg production or a reduction in the fecundity of female worms. The latter has 
been reported for H. contortus females exposed in vivo to different tannin rich materials 
(Martínez-Ortiz-de-Montellano et al., 201 0). To obtain such information it is necessary to 
perform a controlled efficacy protocol (Wood et al., 1995). The AH activity of P. icosandra 
against H. contortus recorded in the present study could be attributable to the different 
compounds contained in the extract (coumarins , flavonoids , steroids, terpenoids , 
saponins) or even combinations of these compounds present in the ethanolic extract. In a 
previous study these compounds were also identified in ethanolic crude extracts of P. 
icosandra (Hernandez-Villegas et al., 2011 ). In the present study additional compounds 
(fatty acids) were also identified in the crude extract using GC/MS analysis. Coumarins 
possess nematodicidal activity against plant parasitic nematodes (Bursaphelenchus 
xylophilus and Panagre/lus redivivus) (Wang et al., 2008) and the free living nematode 
Caenorhabditis e/egans (Liu et al., 2011 ). 
The biological and nematotoxic effects of saponins are normally ascribed to their specific 
interaction with the cell membranes (Tava and Avato, 2006). Saponins may interact with 
the polar heads of membrane phospholipids and the -OH group of cholesterol through OH 
groups at C3 or C28 which will result in their later ability to form micelle-like aggregates . 
Moreover, their hydrophobic aglycone backbone could intercalate into the hydrophobic 
interior of the bilayer (Francis et al., 2002). 8oth of these effects may contribute to the 
alteration of the lipid environment around membrane proteins and with collagen proteins

from the cuticles of nematodes (Argentieri et al., 2008). Meanwhile, Lee et al. (2008) 
screened various naturally occurring flavonoids for AH activity and showed that these 
compounds caused both embryonic and larval lethality in C. elegans. The genistein (a 
form of flavones aglycone) was reported to produce AH effect which was linked to the 
possibility of its activity on nitric oxide synthetase (Kar et al., 2002). The biochemical and 
pharmacological activities of flavonoids have been attributed to their anti-oxidative and 
free-radical scavenging properties (Middleton et al., 2000); however, the molecular basis 
of the high embryonic and larval lethality of flavonoids on C. elegans still needs to be 
elucidated (Lee et al., 2008). 
A form of terpene known as palasonin (a terpene anhydride) was reported to produce AH 
activity by inhibiting glucose uptake and depleting the glycogen content of parasites 
(Kumer et al., 1995). Tarjan and Cheo (1956) discovered the nematicidal activity in most 
of the 41 fatty acids (FAs) or their salts evaluated at 1000 ¡.Jg/m L against the nematode P. 
redivivus, as well as most of the 13 compounds tested against the tobacco cyst nematode 
Globodera tabacum. Myristic, palmitic, and oleic acids were identified as the nematicidal 
principies in benzene extracts of roots of Iris japonica (Chitwood, 2002). Fatty acids esters 
are also nematicidal. The activity of methyl pelargonate (the methyl ester of a C9 fatty 
acid) was demonstrated against Meloidogyne incognita on soybean (Chitwood , 2002). 3-
Hidroxypropionic acid was isolated of severa! endophytic fungi. This compound showed 
selective nematicidal activity against the plant-parasitic nematode M. incognita (Schwarz 
et al., 2004). Ayers et al. (2010), evaluated linoleic acid isolated from the acetone extract 
of Clonostachys candelabrum against H. contortus, exhibited a larval motility reduction of 
90 %. The biological effects of FAs on cells has been suggested that alter membrane 
fluidity either by (i) partitioning into the lipid bilayer of cells or by (ii) inclusion into fatty acyl 
chains of membrane phospholipids or by (iii) binding or altering membrane sterols (Avis 
and Belanger, 2001; Desbois and Smith, 201 0). 
5. Conclusion 
The results of the current study showed that drenching with the ethanolic extract of P. 
icosandra reduced EPG in established infection of H. contortus . lt is therefore concluded 
that the crude extract from leaves of P. icosandra contain compounds with an in vivo AH 
activity against H. contortus in goats. Such activity indicates that the compounds 
contained in the extract at the dose chosen can reach the abomasums in sufficient 
quantity to affect the adult worm population. However, further studies need to test different

dose levels to identify which is the optimal dosage of this crude extract against H. 
contortus in goats.

Abstract 
The resistance of gastrointestinal nematodes (GIN) of small ruminants to anthelmintics 
has required the investigation of new alternatives. The aim of the present study was to 
evaluate the in vivo anthelmintic efficacy of the ethanOI extract from leaves of Phytolacca 
icosandra against GIN in goats. Ten animals that were naturally infected with mixed 
species of GIN were distributed into two groups balanced for their fecal egg counts (FEC) 
were formed (n=S): the non-treated control group and the treated group in which goats 
were individually administered with the ethanol extract of P. icosandra (750 mg/kg body 
weight). The extract was administered orally to animals using a 25 ml syringe. Fecal 
samples were collected from each animal to determine the eggs per gram teces (EPG) for 
14 days post-treatment (PT). The FEC of the two groups were compared using the 
repeated measured analyses of variance using the log transformed data Ln (FEC+1 ). For 
identification of compounds present in the extract standardized methodologies were used. 
The administratio n of the extract of P. icosandra on goat infected with GIN cause a 
decrease in egg excretion and a significant reduction of FEC on day 8 PT. The highest 
reduction rate on FEC of treated animal groups recorded was 56% at dose of 750 mg/kg 
on the day 12 PT (P<O.OS). No adverse reactions were observed in all treated animals for 
the entire trial. The results of phytochemical screening of the ethanol extract of P. 
icosandra revealed the presence of compounds that are known to posses various 
pharmacologic activities and therapeutic uses. From the present study it can be concluded 
that the ethanol extract of P. icosandra exhibits significant anthelmintic against GIN and 
may contribute to integrate control of NGI in goats. 
Keywords: Phytolacca icosandra, Gastrointestinal nematodes , Goats, Anthelmintic 
plants, In vivo anthelmintic activity.

1. lntroduction 
Parasitism by gastrointestinal nematodes (GIN) is a majar constraint in the production of 
small ruminants in the production systems based on grazing or browsing. These infections 
result in weight loss, diarrhoea, dehydration, anaemia, reduced milk production , 
reproductive changes and in severe cases, death (Athanasiadou and Kyriazakis , 2004; 
Botura et al., 2011 ). 
Since the launch of phenothiazine, the first synthetic anthelmintic (AH), more than 50 
years ago, the synthetic chemical AH drugs have been th~ cornerstone for the control of 
GIN infections. However, the constant use of AH treatments to control the GIN often leads 
to the development and diffusion of drug resistance (Torres-Acosta and Hoste, 2008; 
Hoste and Torres-Acosta , 2011 ). This problem is now a worldwide phenomenon , in 
constant expansion , and is particularly prevalent in goats (Jackson and Coop, 2000). This 
constant increase in anthelmintic resistance has stimulated the search for alternative 
solutions, which is also supported by enhanced public concern for more sustainable 
systems of production and less reliant of use of chemical AH drugs (Waller, 1999; 
Jackson, 2000). Among these alternative methods, the use of medicinal plants or plant 
products to treat cases of parasitism are being examined in different parts of the world 
(Githiori et al., 2005; Athanasiadou et al., 2007; Kone and Atindehou , 2008). Evidence of 
the AH properties of plants and plant extracts is derived primarily from the ethnoveterinary 
uses. The effects of these AH plants are related to the activity of secondary metabolites , 
such as tannins, alkaloids, saponins, flavonoids and glycosides (Athanasiadou and 
Kyriazakis, 2004), and the beneficia! properties of these plants on animal health are 
known and exploited by the farming community . On the other hand, they present other 
advantages: they can be of low cost, affordable, well accepted by the small holders and 
locally available (Hoste and Torres-Acosta, 2011 ). 
Phytolacca icosandra (Phytolaccaceae) is used in indigenous systems of medicine to treat 
various ailments such as: scabies, ringworm, dandruff, itching, headache , rheumatism , 
skin irritations, stomach pain and intestinal roundworms of children (Ascaris spp.) 
(Fonnegra and Jimenez, 2007). The ethanolic extract of P. icosandra contains saponins 
coumarins, flavonoids, steroids, terpenoids and fatty acids (the most abundant 
compounds) (Hernández-Villegas et al., 2011; Hernández-Villegas et al., 2012). In in vitro 
conditions, our research group has demonstrated that the ethanolic extract of P. icosandra 
showeda good AH efficacy against eggs (70-97%) and larvae (42-67%) of Haemonchus 
contortus (Hernández-Villegas et al., 2011 ). Furthermore, in in vivo conditions , the 
ethanolic extract of this plant has also demonstrated a good AH efficacy (57-72%) against 
a monospecific infection of H. contortus in goats (Hernández-Villegas et al., 2012);

however, the effect of the ethanolic extract has not been tested against mixed natural 
infection of gastrointestinal nematodes in goats. The aim of the present study was to 
evaluate the in vivo AH efficacy of the ethanolic extract obtained from P. icosandra leaves 
against mixed natural infection of gastrointestinal nematodes in goats. 
2. Materials and methods 
The experiment was conducted at the Faculty of Veterinary Medicine and Animal Science 
(Autonomus University of Yucatán), located in the central region of the state of Yucatán, 
Mexico (21 °15' N lat., 83°32' long.). The region has an annual average rainfall of 953 mm. 
Annual average temperature and humidity of 26.5 oc and 72%, respectively . 
2.1 Plant materials 
P. icosandra leaves were collected in Yaxcabá, Yucatán, México (20° 33' N and 88° 49' 
W) from February to April, 2009. The voucher specimen was authenticated and deposited 
in the herbarium of the Centro de Investigac ión Científica de Yucatán (CICY) under the 
following code number: P. icosandra (MMéndez 1497). 
2.2 Extraction of the plant material 
The extract was obtained from a sample of 1.0 kg of P. icosandra leaves that was dried at 
40 oc for 72 h and ground in a grinder with a 5mm diameter mesh. The ground material 
was immersed in 100% ethanol for 72 h (using 1.0 ml of ethanol per 0.83 g of ground 
material). The ethanol extract was filtered and evaporated at 45 oc in a vacuum rotary 
evaporator (Buchi®) to obtain the crude ethanolic extract.. The process of maceration was 
repeated three times. The crude plant extract was transferred to glass vials and kept at 4 
oc until use. 
2.3 Experimental animals 
Ten criollo female goats (6-8 months year of age) (average body-weight) (BW) of 19.5±5.3 
kg harbouring a naturally acquired infected with GIN were used. The infection were 
confirmed positive before the beginning of the study by collecting fecal samples from the 
animals, by rectum and the number of nematode egg was determined by the McMaster 
technique previously described by Rodríguez-Vivas and Cob-Galera (2005). 
93 • 
Capitulo V 
The animals were pre-adapted to the pen conditions for 21 days prior to the star of the 
study. During this period all animals were monitored at least seven times at interval of 2 
days, to measure the egg per gram of feces (EPG) and balance them according to this 
paramete r. The study continued for a period of 15 days pos-treatment (PT). To determine 
the genera of nematodes coproculture (Corticerlli-Lai technique) was performed by the 
method described by Rodríguez-Vivas and Cob-Galera (2005). The L3 larvae were 
obtained by utilizing the Baermann technique and the generic C!Jmposition was 
determined from the first 50 (L3) by microscopic identification of according to Bowman et 
al. (2004). 
2.4 Treatment 
The animals used for the study were randomly divided into two experimental groups (six 
animals each) adjusted on the basis of eggs per gram of feces (EPG). The negative 
control received 20 ml of a solution of purified water plus Tween 80 (5%) (Sigma­
Aidrich®) (19 ml of purified water and 1 ml of Tween 80) and the treated group received a 
single dose of 750 mg/kg BW of the ethanolic extract of P. icosandra . Briefly, the solution 
of the crude extract was prepared dissolving 750 mg/kg of the crude plant extract in 
Tween 80 (5%) plus purified water (19 ml of purified water and 1 ml of Tween 80). The 
Tween 80 was used to increase the solubility of the extract in aqueous media. 20 ml of 
the solution was administered to the animals using a 25 ml syringe. The extract was 
carefully deposited at the back of the tengue of the sheep. After administrat ion, a volume 
of 50 ml of water was administered to ensure full consumption of the solution. 
The ethanol extract was offered to all animals in the morning before the feed was offered. 
Animals were maintained without food for 14 hours before of ethanolic extract of P. 
icosandra was offered. Clean drinking water was available ad libitum. Food was 
administe red regularly to the study animals (concentrated food and hay). Each group was 
isolated from each other and no physical contact was possible between animals from 
different treatment groups. The animals were monitored daily for changes in behavior, 
feeding or general activity during the PT period. 
2.5 Fecal egg counts 
To determine the fecal egg count reductions (FECR) of strongylida GIN in goats, fecal 
samples of each animal in the respective treatment groups were collected directly from 
the rectum, starting from day O pre-treatment and at 2, 4, 6, 8, 10, 12 and 14 days PT. 
The EPG were determined by the McMaster technique as mentioned above.

Anthelmintic efficacy was estimated calculating the percent FECR, according to the

3. Results 
The in vivo study revealed that no abnormal behavior was observed in animals after 
treatment with ethanol extract of P. icosandra . A reduction in the mean FEC (expressed 
as arithmetic mean of EPG) was demonstrated at day 8-14 PT with significant reduction 
(P<0.05) at day 12 PT (56%) (Table 8) The nematode eggs recovered from the 
experimental animals were identified by fecal cultures as H. contortus (65%), 
Trichostrongy /us spp (20%) and Oesophagostomun columbianum (15%). 
4. Discussi on 
Since the last decade, the number of studies focused to the scientific validation of the 
antiparasitic effects of plants has shown an exponential growth. For sorne plant products, 
like condensed tannins, evidences have accumulated indicating that plants whose AH 
properties have been to sorne extent scientifically validated , might represent a 
valuable solution within the "basket of options" to achieve a more sustainable control of 
gastrointestinal nematodes with a reduced reliance on chemical anthelmintics (Krecek and 
Waller, 2006). The in vivo studies normally have parasitized hosts being treated with 
known quantities of plant products and compared with untreated control or with 
commercial standard anthelmintic . Various measurements are usually recorded and these 
include expulsion of worms and counting parasites in teces, regular worm counts in 
necropsied animals, or daily fecal egg excretion after consumption of plant products 
(Githiori et al., 2006). In our study, fecal eggs excretion was measured to evaluate the 
efficacy of the ethanolic extract against GIN in goats. The preliminary study in vitre of AH 
95 • 
Capitulo V 
activity of the ethanolic extract of P. icosandra on H. contortus was the base to propose 
the evaluation of the AH activity under in vivo conditions. The questions we had to answer 
were if the in vitro AH activity could be extrapolated to in vivo conditions within a mixed 
GIN infections; what animal model would be to choose, what dose level; and what route of 
administration . To answer these questions we reviewed other in vivo protocols with plant 
extracts (Ademola et al., 2007; Botura et al., 2011; Hussain et al., 2011 ). Based on these 
findings we selected the goat model, because this animal species (compared with sheep) 
is better suited to tolerate and detoxify natural toxins, in particular plant secondary 
metabolites (PSM) and it provides a model to explore the balance between various 
regulatory mechanisms of nematode infections (Hoste et al., 2010). The dose level of 750 
mg/kg B.W. was selected based on several studies conducted both in goats and sheep 
where plant extracts were used against GIN (Ademola et al., 2007; Botura et al., 2011; 
Hussain et al., 2011 ). The oral administration route was chosen because it is easy to 
apply in field conditions and it could be used by farmers to make use of ethnoveterinary 
medicine. 
The first reduction in EPG of GIN was found at day 8 PT. However, the highest reduction 
was 56% at day 12 PT (P<0.05). Similar EPG reduction was found by Botura et al. (2011) 
who studied the AH actlvity of the aqueous crude extract of Agave sisalana waste against 
natural GIN infections in goats, achieved a 50% reduction of EPG at day 9 PT when using 
adose of 1.7 g/kg on eight days, that is far superior to that used with P. icosandra in the 
present tria l. Similarly, Macedo et al. (2011) evaluated the Eucalyptus citriodora essential 
oil in goats naturally infected with GIN and found reductions in EPG of 58% at day 22 PT, 
when used 500 mg/kg on three consecutive days. AI-Qarawi et al. (2001) using extracts of 
Ca/otropis procera, found a 49% of EPG reduction in sheep artificially infected with H. 
contortus . Hounzangbe-Adote et al. (2005) tested the effect of the consumption of fagara 
(Zanthoxylum zanthoxyloides) leaves in sheep infected with H. contortus and found that 
the levels of egg excretion were reduced by 57.8%, 48.7% and 41.0% on days 29, 32 and 
35 post infection respectively , using adose of 4 g/kg for three consecutive days. Also the 
work conducted by Eguale et al. (2007) using the aqueous extract of Hedera helix showed 
an EPG reduction of 47% at 2.25 g/kg against H. contortus in sheep. 
The moderate AH activity achieved with the ethanolic extract of P. icosandra could be due 
to a mixed infection of parasites located in different parts of the gastrointestinal tract and 
probably the amount of extract was not enough to achieve a larger reduction . The 
bioavailability of the active compounds at different parts of the gastrointestinal tract, the 
host-plant interactions and the parasite specificity could also have influenced the AH 
activity of the extract. lt has been shown that it is highly likely that certain plants are more 
96 • 
Capitulo V 
active against specific parasite species than others (Athanasiadou et al., 2005; 
Tzamaloukas et al., 2005). Moreover, there is recent evidence suggesting that the 
consumption of medicinal plants or plant extracts has improved the immune response of 
parasitised hosts, by increasing the number of specific effector cells (Tzamaloukas et al., 
2006). However, for most PSM, the host physiological conditions , in particular the ruminal 
conditions and the interactions with the ruminal particles can strongly influence the 
availability of free PSM to interact with the worms and to affect their biology 
(Athanasiadou et al., 2007). Finally, Hoste et al. (2008) suggested that the effect of natural 
AH provoke more a modulation of worm biology than a real nematocidal effect. Therefore , 
the main impact might be through a modulation of epidemiology of infection. 
Consequently , it sounds logical to eventually address the question of the efficiency of AH 
these plants in farm or field studies (Hoste et al., 2008). Use of plants with moderate 
anthelmintic activity should still be considered , perhaps not as a total alternative to 
anthelmintic drugs, but as part of an integrated approach specifically designed to achieve 
sustainable parasite control in ruminant production systems. 
The results obtained in this study showed that ethanolic extract of P. icosandra at the 
dose of 750 mg/kg showed a significant and moderate nematodicidal effect. However, the 
present study encourages further need for research into these cheap indigenous 
althelmintic medicinal plants against the GIN infection in goats. 
5. Conclusion 
Based on the results of the current study, it can be concluded that the ethanolic extract of 
P. icosandra showed significant in vivo AH activity in reducing EPG of mixed species of 
GIN in goats. However, further investigations at different doses and concentrations to 
determine the true potential of P. icosandra asan AH in control strategies against GIN of 
goats are needed.

CAPITULO VI. ANÁLISIS CROMATOGRÁFICOS DE LOS EXTRACTOS 
ORGÁNICOS DE Phytolacca icosandra. 
1. INTRODUCCI ÓN 
Recientem ente, la química de productos naturales ha experimentado un crecimiento 
explosivo debido a los avances en las técnicas de aislamiento, el enfoque de síntesis y 
biosíntesis , así como también los métodos espectroscópicos y cromatográficos (lkan, 
2008). Los esfuerzos por el descubrimiento de fármacos de plantas ha ido evolucionando 
continuamente en respuesta al desarrollo de métodos cromatográficos que permiten la 
reproducción y rápida purificación de diversos compuestos (Bahar et al., 2008). 
Un aspecto importante del uso moderno de extractos de plantas como preparados 
farmacéuticos , es la caracterización y determinación de los constituyentes activos. Los 
extractos crudos de plantas son mezclas complejas de compuestos , por lo tanto es difícil 
aplicar una sola técnica de separación para su aislamiento (Sarker et al., 2006). Para este 
fin, diferentes métodos analíticos se han propuesto para identificar los principales 
compuestos bioactivos. Sin embargo, es más difícil diseñar un protocolo de aislamiento 
para un extracto crudo cuando los tipos de compuestos presentes son totalmente 
desconocidos (Cragg y Newman, 2001 ). En esta situación, es aconsejable llevar a cabo 
ensayos cualitativos para determinar la presencia de varios tipos de compuestos , 
ejemplo, fenoles, esteroides, alcaloides, flavonoides, saponinas , etc (Sarker et al., 2006). 
Con la introducción y desarrollo de nuevas técnicas de bioensayos in vitro 
altamente especificas y el desarrollo de métodos cromatográficos como la cromatografía 
de capa delgada (CCD), la cromatografía de gases (CG), cromatografía de gases 
acoplada a masas (CG-EM) y la cromatografía líquida de alta resolución (CLAR), ha 
hecho mucho más fácil y rápida la determinación , identificación y aislamiento de posibles 
compuestos como fármacos promisorios (Colegate y Molyneux , 2008). 
La cromatografía es una de las técnicas más potentes para la separación , y 
cuantificac ión de compuestos, por tanto fue seleccionada para la obtención del perfil 
cromatográfico de la fracción activa de P. icosandra .

2. MATERIALES Y MÉTODOS 
2.1 Pruebas cualitativas para la determinación de compuestos en los extractos 
orgánicos de P. icosandra 
2.1.1 Determinación de esteroles y terpenos 
La prueba de Salkowsky (Domínguez , 1979) fue utilizada para la detección de 
esteroides y terpenos. Para la determinación de esteroles el procedimiento fue el 
siguiente: se disolvieron 2 mg de la muestra en 1 mL de cloroformo y se adicionó un 
volumen igual de ácido sulfúrico concentrado , formándose dos fases, con un color rojo 
que indica la presencia de esteroles. 
Para la determinación de terpenoides se utilizaron 5 mL de la muestra (2 mg) que 
fueron mezclados en 2 mL de cloroformo y 3 mL de ácido sulfúrico concentrado el cual 
fue adicionado cuidadosamente hasta formar una capa. Una coloración marrón rojiza fue 
observada mostrando resultados positivos de la presencia de terpenoides. 
2.1.2 Determinación de flavonoides 
Para la detección de flavonoides se utilizó la prueba de Shinoda (Domínguez , 
1979). A una disolución alcohólica de la muestra, se le adicionaron 3 virutas de magnesio 
y unas gotas de ácido clorhídrico concentrado . Al adicionar el ácido se observó un 
cambio en la coloración de un amarillo pálido hasta un amarillo intenso que sugiere la 
presencia de flavonas y flavonoles. 
2.1.3 Determinación de saponinas 
La prueba de formación de espuma fue realizada de acuerdo a la metodología 
descrita por Kareru et al. (2008), para la cual se pesaron 2 g del material vegetal 
finamente molido y se colocaron dentro de un tubo de centrifuga de 15 ml. Este material 
fue diluido en 1 O mL de agua destilada. Posteriormente el tubo se agitó vigorosamente 
por aproximadamente 2 min y se dejó en reposo para medir la persistencia de la espuma 
por 30 min. Cuando se agita una disolución acuosa de una muestra que contiene 
saponinas produce espuma que es estable por 15 min o más. 
2.1.4 Prueba de hemólisis 
Esta prueba se desarrolló con base en método descrito por Domínguez , (1979), el 
cual consistió en colocar en cajas de Petri con un medio de cultivo de agar sangre, 
círculos de papel filtro impregnados con el extracto a probar (10 iJL por disco) y un control 
negativo que fue impregnado con el disolvente metano!. La caja inoculada se dejó en 
incubación a 37 °C por 24 h. La detección de la presencia de saponinas se observó como 
halos de hemólisis (zonas claras) alrededor del disco.

2.1.5 Determinación de cumarinas 
Las cumarinas fueron detectadas por determinación del color bajo luz 
ultravioleta (Lock, 1994). La presencia de cantidades significativas de cromóforos en 
estas moléculas permite que puedan ser caracterizadas principalmente a partir de los 
picos de absorción de UV (365 nm) que pueden ser considerados característicos , y 
pueden ser usados fácilmente para su detección (Sarker et al., 2006). 
2.2 Peñil cromatográfico por cromatografía de capa delgada 
La cromatografía en capa delgada (CCD) fue utilizada para determinar e identificar 
el número probable de compuestos presentes en los extractos etanólico, hexánico y 
diclorometano de P. icosandra. Se utilizaron dos sistemas diferentes de disolventes . 
Sistema 1: cloroformo/metanol/agua (7:2:0.25, v/v/v) y sistema 2: cloroformo/metano! 
(95: 1 O, v/v). Se utilizó como revelador el ácido fosfomolíbdico . 
2.3 Peñil cromatográfico por cromatografía de gases-espectrometría de masas 
El extracto etanólico activo de P. icosandra fue analizado en un cromatógrafo de 
gases marca Thermo Scientific modelo Trace Ultra CG, usando un detector de ionización 
de flama, una columna Altech AT™5 con fase estacionaria de fenil metil silicona de 30 
metros de largo 0.32 mm de diámetro interno y el programa de temperatura fue de: TI = 
140 oc, tiempo inicial 2 m in, incrementando 1 O oc, TF = 300 oc, tiempo final 30 m in. El 
análisis de gases masas fue realizado en un cromatógrafo marca Agilent modelo 6890N 
con un detector selectivo de masas marca Agilent modelo 5973 Network. Los análisis 
fueron realizados con una columna HP5 MS de fenil metil silicona de 30 metros de largo, 
0.25 mm diámetro interno y el programa de temperatura fue: TI = 80 oc, tiempo inicial 1 
m in increment ando 15 °C/min hasta 31 o °C, tiempo final 15 m in. 
2.4 Peñil cromatográfico por cromatografía líquida de alta resolución (CLAR) 
El análisis de CLAR fue usado para la obtención del perfil químico y número de 
componentes presentes en cada uno de los extractos de mediana polaridad y polares de 
P. icosandra . El equipo utilizado fue un aparato HPLC marca Perkin-Eimer , modelo 
Flexar, bomba binaria de inyección manual, programa chromera , versión 2.121762. 
Detector de UV-visible modelo Flexar. El análisis cromatográfico se realizó utilizando una 
columna Altima (250 mm • 4.6 mm, tamaño de partícula 5 IJm) empacado con gel de sílice 
fase reversa C-18. Las condiciones cromatográficas fueron las siguientes: concentración 
de la muestra 0.1% = 1 mg en 1000 IJL. La fase móvil utilizada para el extracto etanólico

fue metanol (MeOH)/acetonitrilo (CH3CN) (15:85 v/v) bajo condicion es isocráticas a una 
velocidad de flujo de 0.7 mL/min y una absorbancia de 210 nm. Para los extractos 
diclorometano y acuoso los disolventes utilizados como fase móvil fueron una mezcla de 
CH3CN y H20 en un programa de gradiente con una duración de 30 min y una velocidad 
de flujo 0.7 mL/min; las lecturas fueron realizadas a 280 nm.

Las pruebas cualitativas de los extractos orgánicos de P. icosandra revelaron la 
presencia de esteroles y terpenos por la aparición de un color rojo a marrón después de 
adicionar el reactivo (Prueba de Salkowsky). La presencia de flavonoides fue confirmada 
en los extractos etanólico y de diclorometano de P. icosandra por la aparición de un color 
amarillo después de adicionar unas gotas de ácido clorhídrico (Prueba de Shinoda). Este 
cambio de color fue confirmado por el uso de un control positivo, hesperidina , un 
flavonoide conocido; previamente obtenido de otra especie de planta. La presencia de 
saponinas fue confirmada por la formación de espuma y por su persistencia después de 
agitar la disolución que contenía la muestra. Una de las propiedades que caracterizan a 
las saponinas es la formación de espuma en disoluciones acuosas. Lo anterior es debido 
a la presencia de compuestos polares y no polares que le concede fuertes propiedades 
tensoactivas (Francis et al., 2002). La espuma producida por agitación mecánica es 
típicamen te un sistema termodinámico inestable. Cuando toda la espuma está en reposo,

ésta va desintegréndose paulatinamente . La tasa de debilitamiento define la estabilidad 
de la espuma (Chao-Hsun et al., 2010). La estabilidad de la espuma (más de 15 min) 
mostrada por P. icosandra coincide con lo señalado por varios autores quienes afirman 
que este fenómeno es característico de disoluciones que contienen saponinas . 
Adicionalment e, para confirmar la presencia de saponinas fue realizada la prueba de 
hemólisis en el extracto etanólico de P. icosandra, confirmándose por la presencia de 
halos en los discos impregnados con el extracto, no así en los discos del control negativo 
(Figura 1 0). Y más aún, con los reportes de su presencia en los frutos (Marston y 
Hostettmann , 2006; Treyvaud et al., 2000), se podría sugerir la presencia de estos 
compuestos en otras partes de la planta.

En la CCD el factor de retención (Rf) de los componentes de una mezcla depende 
tanto de la propia polaridad de la muestra como de la polaridad del eluyente y fase 
estacionaria (Domínguez, 1979). En general, los componentes más afines a la fase 
estacionaria (polar en el caso de gel sílice) avanzan lentamente (son más retenidos), 
mientras los más afines a la fase móvil se mueven con mayor rapidez (son menos 
retenidos) . Por lo consiguiente, el medio cromatográfico (placa) funciona como un 
controlador de la velocidad de cada sustancia que constituye la mezcla, logrando así su 
separación .

3.4 Análisis del perfil cromatográfico por cromatografía líquida de alta resolución 
(CLAR) 
El análisis de CLAR fue usado para la obtención del perfil químico y número de 
componentes presentes en cada uno de los extractos polares de P. icosandra . En el 
extracto etanólico fueron detectados once picos con los siguientes tiempos de retención 
(T R): 2.9, 3.4, 3.6, 3.7, 4.6, 5.2, 5.4, 5.6, 6.9, 7.3 y 8.9 m in (Figura 20). En el extracto de 
diclorometano fue detectado un solo pico con T R = 18.3 min (Figura 21 ). De acuerdo al 
tiempo de retención observado de este pico es probable que corresponda a un . 
compuesto de mediana polaridad, ya que los análisis fueron realizados con una columna 
C-18 de fase reversa. En este tipo de columnas la fase estacionaria es no polar, por lo 
tanto, los primeros compuestos eluídos son los polares, seguidos por los de mediana 
polaridad y, por último, los no polares, los cuales son retenidos por la afinidad con la fase 
estacionaria . En el extracto acuoso dos picos fueron detectados por el detector de UV 
designados como A y B. El pico A con T R = 3.45 m in y el pico B con T R = 6.65 min (Figura 
22). 
El análisis del perfil cromatográfico del extracto etanólico mostró una separación 
adecuada de sus componentes, no así los extractos diclorometano y acuoso en los que 
se observa uno y dos picos de absorción, respectivamente. Este comportamiento 
probablemente pueda estar relacionado con la diversidad química y complejidad que 
presentan los extractos crudos, al sistema de elución empleado, o también, a las 
condiciones de corrida de las muestras, por lo tanto no fue posible lograr la separación 
total de los compuestos mediante esta técnica cromatográfica. Para estudios posteriores 
se recomienda utilizar técnicas más específicas y sensibles a compuestos polares como 
la cromatografía de partición de alta velocidad (High Speed Counter Current 
Chromatography); esta técnica puede ser usada para separar compuestos bioactivos con 
una gran diferencia en su polaridad , pero tiene ventajas especiales para el manejo de 
extractos polares que son a menudo difíciles por las técnicas clásicas (Marston y 
Hostettmann, 2006).

CAPÍTULO VIl. DISCUSIÓN Y CONCLUSIONES GENERALES. 
1. DISCUSIÓN GENERAL 
La búsqueda de plantas con actividad antihelmíntica (AH) contra nematodos 
gastrointestinales (NGI) del ganado ha surgido del conocimiento etnoveterinario y de la 
observación de la actividad AH en forrajes ricos en compuestos secundarios, usados 
comúnmente en la alimentación de los rumiantes (Aionso-Díaz et al., 201 0). El 
resurgimiento de este conocimiento ancestral ha sido en parte debido a la aparición e 
incremento de la resistencia antihelmíntica (RA) en poblaciones de NGI, especialmente 
en sistemas extensivos de producción de pequeños rumiantes . Por otra parte, el riesgo 
de residuos químicos que entran en la cadena alimenticia, costos elevados de los AH y la 
creciente demanda del mercado de productos ecológicos o verdes (Waller y Thamsborg , 
2004) ha conducido a la investigación de métodos alternativos para el control de NGI, 
tales como el uso de plantas con propiedades AH. Esta puede ser una alternativa de bajo 
costo, sustentable y que puede ser fácilmente implementada en pequeños productores 
rurales, para lo cual es necesaria la validación científica (in vitro e in vivo) que permita 
conocer el potencial AH de la planta o de sus extractos antes de su aplicación a nivel de 
campo. Una de las principales ventajas de usar ensayos in vitro para la validación de 
plantas o extractos de plantas con propiedades AH, es que son simples, de bajo costo, 
reproducibles y requieren una mínima cantidad de material biológico (Hoste et al., 2008a). 
En el presente trabajo fueron selecionadas tres especies vegetales Sapindus saponaria, 
Momordica charantia y Phytolacca icosandra para su evaluación AH in vitro contra NGI 
de pequeños rumiantes. El primer objetivo fue seleccionar una de las tres especies 
vegetales empleando una prueba in vitro contra larvas infectivas (L3) de Haemonchus 
contortus , evaluando tres extractos de diferente polaridad (etanol, hexano y 
diclorometano) de cada una de las especies, mediante la prueba de inhibición de la 
migración larval (IML) (Rabel et al., 1994). La inhibición de la migración larval de la L3 
usando el extracto etanólico fue observada sólo en P. icosandra 55.4% (P<0.05), en 
cambio, cuando se evaluó el extracto de diclorometano dos de las especies mostraron 
inhibición de la migración larval: M. charantia (47.0%) y P. icosandra (67.0%). Sin 
embargo, sólo el extracto de diclorometano de P. icosandra mostró un efecto dosis­
respuesta en el análisis probit. Por el contrario, en el extracto hexánico no se observaron 
diferencias significativas en las concentraciones evaluadas en las tres especies 
examinadas . En todas las pruebas, el control positivo (Levamisol) mostró 100% de 
inhibición de la migración larval. 
119 • 
Capitulo VI/ 
En general, el efecto AH de las plantas ha sido atribuido a la presencia de 
metabolitos secundarios tales como: taninos, alcaloides , esteroides , saponinas , 
flavonoides y terpenos (Athanasiadou et al., 2007). Estos metabolitos ejercen 
principalmente sus efectos actuando a través de enzimas o por interacción de las 
proteínas con las cuales forman complejos o simplemente interrumpiendo la interacción 
proteína-proteína necesaria para la función normal de la célula (Koehn, 2006). 
El segundo objetivo fue comprobar la eficacia de los extracto~ orgánicos de P. 
icosandra contra la eclosión de huevos de H. contortus . Esta especie fue seleccionada 
debido a la actividad AH mostrada en la prueba de IML. En la prueba de eclosión de 
huevos, más del 95% de inhibición de eclosión de huevos se encontró en los extractos 
etanólico y diclorometano a una concentración de 1.8 y 0.90 mg/mL, respectivamente , 
observándose además un efecto dosis-respuesta en ambos extractos . Por otro lado, las 
concentraciones evaluadas mostraron niveles de eficacia similares al AH sintético 
(Tiabendazol), que inhibió de 95.0 a 98.0% la eclosión de huevos. La prueba de eclosión 
de huevos fue desarrollada originalmente para la detección de resistencia a los 
bencimidazoles en helmintos del ganado. Ésta se basa en la actividad ovicida de este 
grupo de moléculas . Sin embargo, esta prueba ha sido empleada para el tamizaje de 
plantas y extractos de plantas por su alta selectividad y reproducibilidad (Molan et al., 
2002). 
El mecanismo de absorción de los fármacos antihelmínticos en nematodos está 
bien documentado en la literatura. Alvarez et al. (2001) ha descrito dos mecanismos : el 
primero es la difusión del fármaco a través de la superficie externa tales como el 
cascarón y la cutícula de la larva, y el segundo, por difusión a través de las células 
intestinales. Los resultados observados en este estudio con larvas y huevos de H. 
contortus sugieren la posibilidad que la absorción de los compuestos presentes en los 
extractos podría haber ocurrido por difusión transcuticular en la larva infectiva L3 de H. 
contortus y a través del cascarón en los huevos. Esto podría explicarse porque el 
segundo mecanismo de absorción de los fármacos es a través de las células intestinales , 
lo que implicaría que el extracto hubiera sido ingerido por las larvas, condición poco 
probable ya que la larva infectiva L3 no puede alimentarse debido a la presencia de la 
cutícula (vaina) que la protege de las condiciones medio ambientales , incluidas las del 
huésped. Del mismo modo sucedería con el huevo. Los estudios han demostrado que la 
difusión transcuticular es el medio más común de entrada para sustancias no nutritivas y 
no electrolíticas en nematodos. También se ha demostrado que es la ruta predominante 
para la absorción de AH de amplio espectro diferente a la ingestión oral (Geary et al., 
1999). 
120 • 
Capitulo VI/ 
El tercer y cuarto objetivos de este estudio fue la evaluación in vivo del extracto 
etanólico de P. icosandra en una infección artificial monoespecífica de H. contortus y 
también através de una infección natural en cabras. En este trabajo demostré que existe 
una buena correlación entre HPG y cantidad de parásitos (con H. contortus y con 
infecciones mixtas). Se ha encontrado una buena correlación entre el conteo de huevos 
en heces y el conteo de parásitos de H. contortus, pero no para Trichostrongylus 
colubriformis (Sangster et al., 1979), ni para Ostertagia circumcincta (Martin et al., 1985). 
Si el intervalo entre tratamientos es menor de 1 O días, la producción de huev'os podría ser 
suprimida , lo que conduciría a una sobrestimación de la eficacia AH con el bencimidazol 
(Martin et al., 1985). Por esta razón, se recomienda colectar muestras de heces de 10-14 
días PT (Coles et al., 1992). En la prueba de FECRT los animales con infección 
monoespecífi ca de H. contortus que fueron tratados con el extracto etanólico de P. 
icosandra mostraron una reducción en el conteo de huevos por gramo de heces 
comparados con el grupo control que no recibió tratamiento . Esta reducción de la 
excreción de huevos, fue consistente a partir del día 5 PT hasta el final del estudio el día 
15 PT. No se observó ningún cambio de conducta anormal después de la administración 
del extracto a los animales. Las cabras tratadas con el extracto etanólico de P. icosandra 
en la infección monoespecífica mostraron un promedio de reducción del conteo de 
huevos en heces de 62.9% y en la infección natural la reducción fue de 42.0%. Una 
posible explicación sobre porqué se observó una mayor reducción en los animales con 
una infección monoespecífica podría ser debido a que H. contortus se localiza en el 
abomaso, y es probable que en ese órgano existiera una mayor concentración del 
extracto y por lo tanto mayor contacto con el parásito, resultando en una disminución del 
conteo de huevos en heces. Por el contrario, en los animales con infección natural el 
porcentaje de reducción del conteo de huevos fue menor que el encontrado en los 
animales con infección monoespecífica ; esto podría explicarse porque en este tipo de 
infección los parásitos involucrados son de varios géneros y se encuentran alojados en 
diferentes partes del tracto digestivo, lo que compromete la biodisponibilidad de los 
compuestos en el lugar predilecto de los parásitos (Athanasiadou et al., 2007). Dos 
hipótesis han sido planteadas para explicar el posible mecanismo de reducción de 
huevos en heces: la primera supone que existe una reducción en la fecundidad de los 
parásitos hembras (Paolini et al., 2005) y la segunda que puede ocurrir una reducción de 
los parásitos adultos (Heckedorn et al., 2006). Los trabajos utilizando plantas tropicales 
han mostrado consistentemente una reducción en la fecundidad e incluso en el tamaño 
de las hembras y no necesariamente una reducción en la carga de NGI (Martinez-Ortiz­
de-Montellan o et al., 201 O; Galicia-Aguilar et al., 2011 ). En futuros estudios es necesario 
121 • 
Capitulo VI/ 
realizar la prueba de eficacia controlada (Wood et al., 1995) para determinar si la 
actividad AH puede ser atribuida a la supresión temporal de la producción de huevos de 
las hembras o al efecto nematicida del extracto. 
El quinto objetivo de esta tesis fue la determinación cualitativa de los compuestos 
secundarios presentes en los extractos de P. icosandra . La detección preliminar de los 
constituye ntes químicos en un extracto, puede ser determinada por medios 
calorimétricos ; esta metodología es sencilla, rápida, sensible y requ,iere de cantidades 
minoritarias de muestras (Oomínguez , 1979). Las reacciones químicas de coloración, 
precipitación y de fluorescencia , junto con las propie'dades físicas nos permitieron 
detectar la existencia de varios compuestos tales como cumarinas , esteroles, flavonoides , 
terpenos y saponinas . 
El sexto objetivo fue obtener el perfil cromatográfico de los extractos activos de P. 
icosandra por cromatografía de capa delgada (CCO), cromatografí a de gases­
espectrometría de masas (CG-EM) y por cromatografía de líquidos de alta resolución 
(CLAR). Los extractos crudos vegetales literalmente son un coctel de compuestos de 
polaridad distinta, por lo tanto es difícil aplicar una sola técnica de separación para aislar 
cada uno de los compuestos presentes en el extracto. La ceo es un método 
ampliamente utilizado para analizar y comparar los componentes presentes en una 
mezcla, tales como los extractos de plantas. Los perfiles cromatográficos por ceo de los 
extractos orgánicos de P. icosandra, mostraron que contiene un gran número de 
compuestos. Cabe mencionar que es en el extracto etanólico donde se encuentra la 
mayoría de los compuestos, y esto se debe a la capacidad que tienen los disolventes 
alcohólicos para incrementar la permeabilidad de la pared celular, facilitando la extracción 
eficiente de grandes cantidades de compuestos polares, de mediana polaridad y de baja 
polaridad (Sarker et al., 2006). Esto podría explicar en parte la actividad AH contra 
múltiples blancos (larvas, huevos y parásitos adultos).de este extracto. 
Una variedad de técnicas analíticas han sido usadas para la caracterización de 
compuestos en una mezcla (extractos) . Sin embargo, la CG-EM es recomendada para la 
separación e identificación de compuestos volátiles y semivolátiles ; esta técnica permite 
la separación de los compuestos de una mezcla en picos individuales ; por lo tanto, fue 
usada para la obtención del perfil cromatográfico de los extractos etanólico y de 
diclorometano de P. icosandra . Si bien no fue posible identificar todos los picos, los 
compuestos identificados corresponden a ácidos grasos y a un estero!. 
Existe evidencia que los ácidos grasos pueden influenciar el sistema inmune. Las 
investigaciones realizadas en los últimos treinta años sugieren que el cambio de ácidos 
grasos en la nutrición puede ser un medio para modificar el comportamiento de las 
122 • 
Capitulo VIl 
células inmunes y la respuesta inmune, incluyendo su componente inflamator io 
(Calder, 2008). Los ácidos grasos cumplen una variedad de funciones dentro de las 
células inmunes tales como: combustibles para generación de energía; como 
componentes de fosfolípidos de las células de membrana , ya que contribuyen a las 
propiedades físicas y funcionales de las membranas ; como precursores para la síntesis 
de mediadores bioactivos tales como prostaglandinas, leucotrienos y lipoxinas y como 
reguladores de expresión de genes a través de los efectos sobre la actividad del receptor 
' o sobre los procesos de señalización intracelular o en la activación del factor de 
transcripción (Calder, 2008). La presencia de ácidos grasos en los extractos etanólicos de 
P. icosandra podría haber influido de manera indirecta en el incremento de la respuesta 
inmune del huésped. Se ha obtenido evidencia en diferentes razas de cabras que indican 
que la regulación inmune de poblaciones de nematodos ocurre por reducción del 
crecimiento larval y/o por afectar la producción de huevos (Hoste et al., 2008b) como ha 
quedado demostrado en el presente trabajo. 
El análisis del extracto etanólico de P. icosandra empleando CLAR indica que éste 
contiene una mezcla de compuestos , no así el extracto de diclorometano y acuoso en el 
cual fueron detectados uno y dos picos respectivamente . El CLAR es una técnica 
analítica de separación , ampliamente utilizada para la determinación cualitativa y 
cuantitativa de compuestos en extractos de productos naturales (Sarker et al., 2006). Una 
de las desventajas que presenta esta técnica, es que algunos compuestos no presentan 
grupos cromóforos y por lo tanto no pueden ser detectados al UV, pero existen formas de 
superar este problema mediante el empleo de la detección de índice de refracción , 
(Hostettmann y Marston, 1995). El detector de índice de refracción fue utilizado también 
en el análisis de CLAR del extracto etanólico, pero no fue posible la detección de 
compuestos debido a la gran sensibilidad de este tipo de detectores a cambios de 
temperatura , cambios de presión y cambios en la tasa de flujo, aunque las condiciones de 
corrida fueron isocráticas algunos de estos factores podrían haber influido y no permitir 
la detección del índice de refracción .

2. CONCLUSIONES 
);> De las tres especies vegetales evaluadas in vitro contra la larva infectiva L3 de 
Haemonchus contortus , Phytolacca icosandra demostró mejor actividad antihelmíntica en 
la prueba de inhibición de la migración larval. 
);> En la prueba de eclosión de huevos de H. contortus los extractos etanólico y 
diclorometano mostraron una eficacia antihelmíntica similar al antih~lmíntico sintético 
tiabendazol. 
);> El extracto hexánico de P. icosandra no mostró actividad antihelmíntica en ninguna de las 
concentraciones evaluadas . 
);> En la prueba in vivo en cabras infectadas artificialmente con H. contortus el extracto 
etanólico de P. icosandra demostró eficacia antihelmíntica al reducir consistentemente la 
excreción de huevos en heces. 
);> Los resultados de la prueba in vivo confirmaron la actividad antihelmíntica encontrada en 
las pruebas in vitro contra H. contortus. 
);> En cabras infectadas naturalmente el extracto etanólico de P. icosandra mostró un efecto 
antihelmíntico moderado con 56% de reducción en el conteo de huevos. 
);> No se observaron signos de toxicidad en los animales ni cambios de conducta después 
que fueron tratados con el extracto etanólico de P. icosandra ni durante todo el estudio. 
);> La cromatografía de gases-masas permitió la identificación de cinco compuestos : 
6,1 O, 14-trimetil-2-pentadecanona , éster etílico del ácido hexadecanoico-4 ,8, 12,16-
tetrametilheptadecan-4-ólido , estigmasta-7,25-dien-3-ol y el ácido pentadecanoico , 
presentes en los extractos etanólico y diclorometano de P. icosandra . 
);> El análisis por cromatografía líquida de alta resolución no permitió la separación total de 
los compuestos presentes en cada uno de los extractos de P. icosandra. 
);> Por último, se concluye que el extracto etanólico d.e hojas de P. icosandra contiene 
compuestos con actividad antihelmíntica in vitro e in vivo contra nematodos 
gastrointe stinales de pequeños rumiantes .

3. PERSPECT IVAS 
En estudios futuros se propone la experimentación in vivo en cabras infectadas 
artificialmente con Haemonchus contortus y en cabras infectadas naturalmente (infección 
mixta), para confirmar cuál es la concentración del extracto etanólico de P. icosandra 
requerida para lograr una mayor reducción de huevos en heces y evaluar un posible 
efecto dosis-dependiente . 
Realizar estudios a través de la prueba de eficacia controlada , para evaluar la 
actividad ovicida o nematocida del extracto etanólico de P. icosandra en cabras 
infectadas artificialmente con H. contortus . 
Llevar a cabo un experimento in vivo para evaluar su posible uso como nutracéutico 
en pequeños rumiantes . 
Evaluar el uso del extracto etanólico de P. icosandra como desparasitante en 
ovinos infectados artificialmente (infección monoespecífica) y naturalmente con 
nematodos gastrointestinales . 
Profundizar en los estudios fitoquímicos para identificar y aislar los compuestos 
activos del extracto etanólico de P. icosandra para su valoración in vitro y su posible 
evaluación in vivo de los compuestos puros.
